columns.text: In this exercise, we are going to learn about the option to wait.

In this requirement, we are going to use the concept of net present value. 

The **net present value (NPV)** is the present value of initial investment or cash outflow less the present value of the cash inflows. 

It is used to evaluate if an investment should be pursued or not. If the NPV is positive, then it should be continued, otherwise, it should be rejected.

Here are the parameters to solve the problem: 


|Given | | 
|--|--| 
|Cost of new machine |$1,800,00 | 
|Increase in cash flow from new machine |$275,000/year | 
|Useful life of new machine |10 years | 
|Required rate of return |8% | 

Additional information is as follows: 

- The cost of the machine will decline by $140,000 annually until its cost is $1,100,000.

The net present value is solved as follows: 

  

$$\textbf{NPV}=\text{PV of Cash Inflows}-\text{Initial Investment}$$

The initial investment is deducted from the present value of cash inflows to determine the net present value.

Whereas, the present value of cash inflows is solved as follows: 

  

$$\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}=\text{Cash Inflow}\times\text{PV Factor}$$

The cash inflows are multiplied by the present value factor to determine the present value of cash inflows.

## Annual cost of the machine

To start with, let us solve the annual cost of the machine.

At Year 0, the cost of the machine is $1,800,000. 

Now, in Year 1, the cost of the machine is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cost}&=\$1,800,000-\$140,000\\[15pt]
&=\$1,660,00
\end{aligned}$$

In Year 1, the cost of the machine is $1,660,000.

Next, let us solve the cost of machine in Year 2: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cost}&=\$1,660,000-\$140,000\\[15pt]
&=\$1,520,00
\end{aligned}$$

In Year 2, the cost of the machine is $1,520,000.

Now, let us solve the cost of machine in Year 3: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cost}&=\$1,652,000-\$140,000\\[15pt]
&=\$1,380,00
\end{aligned}$$

In Year 3, the cost of the machine is $1,380,000.

Then, let us solve the cost of machine in Year 4: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cost}&=\$1,380,000-\$140,000\\[15pt]
&=\$1,240,00
\end{aligned}$$

In Year 4, the cost of the machine is $1,240,000.

Then, let us solve the cost of machine in Year 5: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cost}&=\$1,240,000-\$140,000\\[15pt]
&=\$1,100,00
\end{aligned}$$

In Year 5, the cost of the machine is $1,110,000. 

From Years 6 to 10, the cost of the machine is $1,100,000.

## Present Value of Cash Inflows

Let us solve the present value of cash inflows at Year 0 using the equation in Step 5: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}&=\$275,000\times6.7101\\[15pt]
&=\$1,845,442.50
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of cash inflows at Year 0 is $1,845,442.50.

Now, the present value of cash inflows at Year 1 is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}&=\$275,000\times6.2469\\[15pt]
&=\$1,717,897.50
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of cash inflows at Year 1 is $1,717,897.50.

Now, the present value of cash inflows at Year 2 is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}&=\$275,000\times5.7466\\[15pt]
&=\$1,580,315
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of cash inflows at Year 2 is $1,580,315.

Now, the present value of cash inflows at Year 3 is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}&=\$275,000\times5.2064\\[15pt]
&=\$1,431,760
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of cash inflows at Year 3 is $1,431,760.

Then, the present value of cash inflows at Year 4 is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}&=\$275,000\times4.6229\\[15pt]
&=\$1,271,297.50
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of cash inflows at Year 4 is $1,271,297.50.

Then, the present value of cash inflows at Year 5 is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}&=\$275,000\times3.9927\\[15pt]
&=\$1,097,992.50
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of cash inflows at Year 5 is $1,097,992.50.

Then, the present value of cash inflows at Year 6 is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}&=\$275,000\times3.3121\\[15pt]
&=\$910,827.50
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of cash inflows at Year 6 is $910,827.50.

Then, the present value of cash inflows at Year 7 is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}&=\$275,000\times2.5771\\[15pt]
&=\$708,702.50
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of cash inflows at Year 7 is $708,702.50.

Then, the present value of cash inflows at Year 8 is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}&=\$275,000\times1.7833\\[15pt]
&=\$490,407.50
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of cash inflows at Year 8 is $490,407.50.

Then, the present value of cash inflows at Year 9 is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}&=\$275,000\times0.9259\\[15pt]
&=\$254,622.50
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of cash inflows at Year 9 is $254,622.50.

## Net Present Value

Using the equation in Step 4, the net present value at Year 0 is solved below: 

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{NPV}&=\$1,845,442.50-\$1,800,000\\[15pt]
&=\$45,442.50
\end{aligned}$$


Thus, the net present value at Year 0 is $45,442.50.

The net present value at Year 1 is solved below: 

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{NPV}&=\$1,717,897.50-\$1,660,000\\[15pt]
&=\$57,897.50
\end{aligned}$$


Thus, the net present value at Year 1 is $57,897.50.

The net present value at Year 2 is solved below: 

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{NPV}&=\$1,580,315-\$1,520,000\\[15pt]
&=\$60,315
\end{aligned}$$


Thus, the net present value at Year 2 is $60,315.

The net present value at Year 3 is solved below: 

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{NPV}&=\$1,431,760-\$1,380,000\\[15pt]
&=\$51,760
\end{aligned}$$


Thus, the net present value at Year 3 is $51,760.

The net present value at Year 4 is solved below: 

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{NPV}&=\$1,271,297.50-\$1,240,000\\[15pt]
&=\$31,297.50
\end{aligned}$$


Thus, the net present value at Year 4 is $31,297.50.

The net present value at Year 5 is solved below: 

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{NPV}&=\$1,097,992.50-\$1,100,000\\[15pt]
&=(\$2,007.50)
\end{aligned}$$


Thus, the net present value at Year 5 is ($2,007.50).

The net present value at Year 6 is solved below: 

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{NPV}&=\$910,827.50-\$1,100,000\\[15pt]
&=(\$189,172.50)
\end{aligned}$$


Thus, the net present value at Year 6 is ($189,172.50).

The net present value at Year 7 is solved below: 

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{NPV}&=\$708,702.50-\$1,100,000\\[15pt]
&=(\$391,297.50)
\end{aligned}$$


Thus, the net present value at Year 7 is ($391,297.50).

The net present value at Year 8 is solved below: 

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{NPV}&=\$490,407.50-\$1,100,000\\[15pt]
&=(\$609,592.50)
\end{aligned}$$


Thus, the net present value at Year 8 is ($609,592.50).

The net present value at Year 9 is solved below: 

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{NPV}&=\$254,622.50-\$1,100,000\\[15pt]
&=(\$845,377.50)
\end{aligned}$$


Thus, the net present value at Year 9 is ($845,377.50).
